project.teaser: The current drive-train solutions for bottom-fixed offshore wind turbines do not necessarily work well for floating wind turbines, especially when it comes to increasing the size of the turbines beyond the current state of the art. The increasing nacelle weight makes it...
project.objective: The current drive-train solutions for bottom-fixed offshore wind turbines do not necessarily work well for floating wind turbines, especially when it comes to increasing the size of the turbines beyond the current state of the art. The increasing nacelle weight makes it difficult to develop floating platforms that are both technically and economically viable beyond 15 MW. Also, high repair costs of current drive-train solutions are making sites far off coast (which would be technically viable for floating wind turbines) economically unacceptable. Innovation is needed to develop new solutions for floating wind turbines that can reduce the weight of nacelle and rotor and subsequently also of the supporting structures, while maintaining or increasing energy production and decreasing repair costs. This project proposes to develop a disruptive, compact and lightweight drive-train solution, that offers significant advantages in terms of mass, turbine and repair costs, scalability, critical materials usage, and social and environmental impacts. The LIGHTWIND project aims at demonstrating the technical feasibility of the concept and at evaluating the economic, social, and environmental benefits by comparing it to existing 15 MW turbine reference models. Additionally, the project will demonstrate that these benefits allow the scaling of floating offshore wind turbines to 22 and 30 MW.
project.title: LIGHTWIND: A DISRUPTIVE DRIVE-TRAIN FOR ULTRALIGHT AND LOWER COST WIND TURBINES
project.keywords: wind energy, floating offshore wind, drive-train, rotor, LCOE, weight reduction

article.title: New turbine design unlocks full potential of wind energy in deep waters
article.teaser: The LIGHTWIND project’s wind turbine technology shows how floating offshore wind turbines can be lighter, cheaper, and easier to inspect and repair.

article.title: What’s the progress on clean energy innovation?
Smooth sailing for new floating wind farm platform
Online monitoring technology for safer and more cost-efficient mooring operations

result.title: Reference WTG and WF characterized
result.description: Report describing including description and specifications of the reference wind turbine generator (REF15), based on existing reference turbines. The report will also include the main parameters of a wind farm WF using that REF15.Task 5.1: 15 MW reference scenario definition, turbine levelTask 5.2: 15 MW reference scenario definition, WF level

result.title: Component level validation plans
result.description: Validation plans for elastomeric mounts and wheel-rail assembly.The validation plans will describe the high-level concept of the test set-up to be used (including selection of materials and material combinations to be tested), the way the loads are to be applied, test cases to be tested and, if applicable the expected results.Task 3.2: Wheel-rail initial methodology formulation + validation planTask 3.3: Elastomeric mounts initial methodology formulation + validation plan

result.title: OG mechanical RNA concept OG15a
result.description: PPT describing the RNA concept, based on a CAD 3D assembly and drawings showing the location and dimensions of the key components. Also relevant information for the simulation, as the weights, mass center of gravities, and the stiffness matrices will be included. The native CAD files will not be included. Task 2.2: Initial OptiGen 15 MW RNA design OG15a

result.title: Project management plan – first version
result.description: The management plan includes all the essential aspects necessary for effective project management, containing a Gantt chart and a Work Breakdown Structure (WBS).Task 1.1: Project coordination

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
